context/1: Also the kind they had in 1914 when officers fought with only a swagger stick.
context/2: That kind of guts.
context/4: "Into the valley of death rode the 600."
context/5: He's got guts.
context/6: I'll say this for the old man.
context/7: You see, Jennings, there are advantages to being on the sick list.
context/8: Murdering unarmed men?

context/0: He's leading him right to it!
context/2: I think we better have a look around before that train comes across.
context/3: Colonel, there's something rather odd going on.
context/5: River's gone down in the night.
context/7: As you once said, sir, I've got a lot to learn about the army.
context/8: Honestly, sometimes I don't understand you at all.

context/0: L pill?
context/2: By the way, here's something that'll interest you.
context/3: It's almost as if your whole escape had been planned with us in mind.
context/4: Your knowledge of the area, making friends in that village.
context/5: You don't realise what a plum you are for us.
context/7: Well, feel like a sniff of air?
context/8: Yes, sir.
context/9: All right, Chapman, you can run along.

context: I didn't know you had company, Mrs. Brenner.
response: I'd better come back some other time.
context/0: You'd be surprised at some of the tricks they've tried.
context/1: And this time if you don't mind, I'll take a little look around.
context/2: Thanks.
context/4: Or else I might have to raise the price on you.
context/5: And no more tricks.
context/8: Yes.
context/9: Do you hear me, Mrs. Brenner?

context: It was a good idea that you sent that paper... with the image of a bat.
response: I immediately knew you were trying to rescue me.
context/0: It was a good idea that you sent that paper...
context/2: I need his help to organize my papers.
context/5: In two or three days.
context/8: Eduardo, why don't we leave the country and forget this.

context/0: How do you know?
context/1: But not the renegades we're looking for.

context/3: Sir, we ran across a band of Cheyenne off the reservation.

context/8: Oh, send him right in.

response: Buffalo, New York, that's where I'm calling from.
context/0: I'm 300 miles from home without a penny in my pocket.
context/1: Say, what are you gonna do about me?
context/2: Hello CBS?

context/4: Is that what you call entertainment?
context/5: The whole house was in an uproar.
context/6: All the kids were screaming their heads off.
context/8: A fine trick the play on people.

context: So this man calls from L.A. last night.
response: He give me the name of Stokes.
context/0: The district attorney included.
context/2: Some people might think I was overzealous.
context/3: Taking charge of an estate before there was an estate.
context/5: If he is, I've committed a crime or two.

response: Buy a flower for your young lady, Sir,
context/0: You're twisting my words.
context/1: I didn't say that at all.
context/2: Now, wait a minute, I didn't say that.
context/3: So you have made no progress then?
context/4: You can't expect us to nab the man instantly when he left no clues at all.
context/5: Now, see here, this only happened the night before last.
context/6: No, I'm afraid the public won't accept that in this case, Sergeant.
context/7: To report at an early date.
